data.text: Is It Necessary to Camp when Bike Touring? Can I Stay at Hotels?
Hello, allow me to ask a newbie question. Does it necessary do camping for bike touring? How far can you go if you rely on hostels, b&b, motelsâ€¦? Thank you.
As long as your credit cards last ðŸ˜‰
data.author: Thomas Sinotte

data.text: And how far between accomidations so it depend on your route and country
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: We usually combine and go with what we feel like and depends on the weather.
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: Also depends on the country you are cycling un.
data.author: Scott Fowler

data.text: As far as you can afford.
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: I rode from Seattle to Boston on the historic Hwy 20. 75 days in motels. It just took a bit of planning (no more than 10 days in advance to allow for flexibility)
data.author: Radfield Justice

data.text: Thank you so much for sharing. This is great. What is the longest ride mileages in one day in your trip?
data.author: Cy Chang

data.text: mileage is gonna vary widely depending on what distances you're comfortable riding and on the terrain (for example on a bike packing trip on the C&O Canal trail in MD and VA I did ~70 miles/day because it's all flat, I was just chilling at like 8mph but got an early start and was comfortable to be in the saddle for 10 hours, versus on the same bike and in better shape I probably averaged 45 miles a day while doing the Oregon Outback trail because there was way more climb and the terrain was not always nice packed gravel). The hardest part of mileage is making sure your butt and your hands can handle the pressure all day! I often look at a couple options for where I'll stay that night, like if I only go 50 miles I'll stay here but the next place is another 30 miles then I'll only stay there if I'm feeling real good and making great time that day. But I'm also usually doing a mix of camping and hotels so worst case I can always stealth camp if I really misjudge my ability that day haha
data.author: Annemarie Lucernoni

data.text: Thank you so much! Your experience gives me confidence and understanding on my future plan. Thank you..
data.author: Cy Chang

data.text: I averaged 50. The shortest 28, the longest 82.
data.author: Radfield Justice

data.text: Did you hear of communities like #WarmShowers #trustroots and so on? So far we did cycle about 3.500 km from Hamburg, Germany via France, Italy and Greece to Turkey (3 nights on ferries) in about 4 months. We payed for accommodation 1 night in Germany, 0 nights in France, 5 nights in Italy and 5 nights in Greece (because I got sick). Other nights we were hosted by very nice people or camped wild about 30/70. We love the freedom to just cycle as far as we want and put our tent down. Sometimes you like a nice bed sure, but it is a hazzle to plan the route so detailed and find a host or a room. We rather spend that time having the adventure of our lifetime on Amazing World Bike Tour
data.author: Mathias Kissling

data.text: It depends where you tour, whether non-camping facilities are available.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Necessary? It is compulsory! If you are not wild camping and defecating in a bag everyday leave this group immediately. Only joking ðŸ˜€. Do touring whatever way feels good to you and just ignore anyone who tries to tell you different. I personally enjoy very much loading my folding bike on an overnight train and waking up hundreds of kilometers down the road. I am also looking forward to my next trip in Sth Korea where I plan to try to spend every night I can in a jjimjilbang 24 HR Korean style public bathhouse.
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: A friend of mine road across the country staying in hotels. They had all reservations made, including their return flight, before they left. Not my choice on how to do it, but it can be done. It must have been a blessed trip because on the entire trip they had no flats, no crashes, and no mechs.
data.author: Jim McCorison

data.text: that took some planning. Wow, didn't miss a single reservation?
data.author: Robert Gransbury

data.text: Nope. Although things changed a bit. They did hit all the stops and the flight back home.
data.author: Jim McCorison

data.text: you might consider going somewhere and riding home as each day you are closer to home takes a bit of pressure off a limited time given on a journey.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Only old people tour that way

data.author: Radfield Justice

data.text: Plan the route dependant on how you can personally ride

data.author: Mark Randlesome

data.text: Thanks for sharing! I have been watching YouTube videos for tips and inspiration. Iâ€™ll check it out
data.author: Sherry Brosseau

data.text: We have toured unsupported on our tandem in Italy, France, Germany, Austria, Nova Scotia, Quebec and the United States. Each trip was carefully planned in advance to include reservations each night at an inn, bed and breakfast, or hotel. Daily distances ranged from 45 to 65 miles, touring for two weeks at a time. We carry tools and parts to repair the bike if needed. We have never camped when touring. Inn-to-inn touring distance is only limited by the time you have available to do it if you reserve your accommodations in advance. The downside of this approach is you must stay on schedule regardless of weather or illness.
data.author: Bernie Derry

data.text: Can totally be done, just not in the more remote parts of the world. And on the plus side you can definitely do more kms per day because you're carrying less gear.
data.author: Louise Sensi

data.text: Hotels, friends sofas, wild camping, anywhere at all
data.author: David Farnsworth

data.text: Itâ€™s a trade-off. Camping allows for more freedom but requires more gear. Indoor accommodations require more planning and money.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I heard it's hard to get a warm showers host in july/august cause 'everybody' is cycling then. Can anyone confirm that? Or rather disproveðŸ˜‰. I would like to go on a 5 week trip in france during that time without camping.

data.author: Jasmin Gray

data.text: There is a best of both worlds option, many campsite will have statics lodges or glamorous tents already set up you can just hire them for the time you want them, campsites are rarely close to big interesting towns but often have large open air swimming pools and excellent showers so you you choose what is important and whatâ€™s essential, happy trailâ€™s
data.author: Lupus Baker

data.text: As far as your wallet will take you
data.author: Darrell Sullivan

data.text: 1) No, 2) As far as you want to go. I do "credit card" touring and highly recommend a warm shower and comfy bed at the end of each night.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: 1000% agree.
data.author: Lou Roussinos

data.text: the basic question is what to do, if you dont find accomodations.....and how basic can you go, when you are stuck......lightweight tarps, do wonders and are extremely light and compactable....also lightweight bivies, help keep you dry and protected from the wind....you know you have.....arrived, when you pass up a fancy place for your basic set up......
data.author: Philip Buckley

data.text: I rode from San Diego to Key West with no camping. Then from Key West to Bar Harbor Maine. Does nobody use the cycling maps anymore? They tell you where services are so you can plan your ride. Adventure Cycling has maps of all major routes in the US.
data.author: Susan Fowler

data.text: the Adventure Cycling maps have become costlier and using Garmin and Openstreet you can locate everything that there is on those maps and more since the gpx files are fresher.
data.author: Lou Roussinos

data.text: For a short trips sometimes I like to â€œnotâ€œ bring my camping gear. I make reservations in advance (hotels, b&b). For a short trip itâ€™s easy to stick to a planning. For longer trips (weeks or months) my camping gear gives me more freedom and flexibility, and requires less planning. I can decide to have shorter or longer days on the saddle, change my itinerary for whatever reason, or spend one more day in a place that I like very much. At the end, it up to you to decide whatâ€™s best for you.
data.author: Jean Flamand

data.text: Depends which part of the country you're in. I live in California so we have mostly camped during our tours. Currently planning Boston to D.C. so will do hotels/hostels along the way
data.author: Mikaela Kerkman

data.text: If you have enough money you can hire a dozen supermodels to drive behind you in a tour bus and stay in that
data.author: Clay Pardue
